(Thanks to Pranav Prabhu for requesting this answer.) [Disclaimer: I’m an undergrad, not an expert. I’ll answer within my best knowledge.] Yes, it does curve space time - photons of light carry energy, and in relativity we consider mass and energy to be essentially equivalent, referring to “mass-energy” as one quantity. Photons, therefore, do cause some bending of spacetime near to them, just as an object with mass would. However, this effect is ridiculously tiny for any kind of laser beam we could actually create. It takes a lot of mass/energy to curve spacetime enough to cause noticeable effects. Think about how much energy there is in your body according to [math]E = mc^2[/math]! And you can’t cause any noticeable effects due to the curvature of spacetime with your presence, even with all that energy! So although technically yes, it would “attract” nearby objects, the same goes for your body, or your computer, or a pencil. It’s only “technically”; the effects are minuscule.
